rows.title: Safe water source tips

text.eng: You can get water from many sources. The safest water is often from a tap.  Water from unprotected streams, open sources (such as the lake) and open dug wells may have bugs (parasites) which can make us sick. They may also have stool from animals or humans.  This can make it unsafe!

rows.title: Transporting and storing water

text.eng: Make sure that water that is carried and stored does not come into contact with hands, dirt or insects. Hands, dirt and insects make water unsafe to drink.

Extract - For water stored in the home, protection from contamination can be achieved by use of enclosed or otherwise safely designed storage containers that prevent the introduction of hands, dippers or other extraneous sources of contamination.

Storage containers should preferably be fitted with a mechanism such as a tap or outlet pipe
that enables hygienic abstraction of water.
rows.title: Using a water container

text.eng:
Water should be carried in clean and closed water containers.

There are many designs for water containers.  A safe water storage container is one that is:

* Strong and has a tightly fitting lid or cover
* Stable base so it does not tip over
* Durable so that it does not leak easily
* Has a comfortable handle
* And, of course, easy to clean

Mushi, M. F., Mpelasoka, O. E., Mazigo, H. D., McLeod, L., Moremi, N., Mirambo, M. M., & Mshana, S. E. (2018). High rate of drinking water contamination due to poor storage in squatter settlements in Mwanza, Tanzania. Tanzania Journal of Health Research, 20(3). https://doi.org/10.4314/thrb.v20i3.7

Source of drinking water in the squatters of Mwanza city - All households used tap water as the source of their drinking water. A total of 157 (75.84%) respondents, reported treating their water for drinking using boiling, 119 (57.49%) leaving the water to stand and settle, 23 (11.11%) used chlorination and 15 (9.6%) strain through cloth (Table1). The majority of households 202 (97.58%) stored their drinking water; of these 200 (98.55%) used a clay pot. Only 2 (1%) used buckets with cover and spigot as storage container of drinking water.

rows.title: How do you keep your container clean?

title.eng: How do you keep your container clean?

text.eng:
Step 1: Wash your hands following the steps in the how to wash your hands module.
Step 2: Pour clean and soapy water into the container. 
Step 3: Put on the lid and shake for one minute (or if you can scrub the inside of the container). 
Step 4:  Pour the soapy water out. Rinsing next with non soapy water. 
Also, don't forget to wash your cup after every use.

Extract
Whichever method is used locally, children should learn how to treat water for drinking.  If using heat to disinfect, the water should be boiled and remain boiling for at least 10 minutes to make sure all pathogens are killed before use. Boiled water should be stored, handled carefully and consumed within 24 hours to avoid recontamination. If sunlight is used to disinfect small quantities of water, the bottles should be filled with pre-filtered, clear water and set out in the sun (usually on rooftops) for 6 hours.
rows.reference_link_title: Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene for School Children. UNICEF; 2021.
rows.title: Treating water by boiling

text.eng: Boiling water can make it safe to drink or cook with. Let the water sit for some time until the dirt settles at the bottom. Pour it into a pot and boil it for at least 10 minutes to make sure all the germs (pathogens) are killed before using it. Drink the water within 24 hours. This helps to keep it clean, fresh and free from other germs (pathogens).
